title: 114_hr4042
content: The Act may be cited as the "Pre-K for USA Act." The Pre-K for USA Act finds that the United States ranks 25th in early learning enrollment, children in high-quality prekindergarten programs are more successful in their careers, every public dollar spent on prekindergarten programs returns $7, and children who attend prekindergarten are less likely to develop drug problems or commit felonies. Children who attended prekindergarten have lower chances of developing drug problems, committing felonies, or going to prison. They also tend to have higher GPAs, are more likely to attend a four-year college, but about 40% of school districts do not offer prekindergarten programs. Texas missed out on significant federal funding to expand prekindergarten programs due to budget cuts in education funding. In 2011, Texas cut $5.4 billion in education funding, including $200 million in grants for full-day prekindergarten programs. Local governments stepped in to fund these programs, highlighting the need for direct federal funding for prekindergarten programs. SEC. 3. PREKINDERGARTEN DEVELOPMENT GRANTS. The Secretary of Education, in consultation with the Secretary of Health and Human Services, will award competitive grants to increase capacity for high-quality prekindergarten programs. Grants will be awarded for up to 3 years and applications must be submitted by Governors or chief executive officers of eligible entities. The Act requires submission of an application to the Secretary of Education, along with necessary information. States must consult with the State Advisory Council on Early Childhood Education and Care when developing the grant application. A matching requirement mandates that non-Federal funds equal to at least 20% of the grant amount must be contributed by the State or local government entity to be eligible for the grant. The government entity must provide non-Federal matching funds of at least 20% of the grant amount. This can be done through State funding, local funding, philanthropy, in-kind contributions, or a combination of resources. The Secretary may waive or reduce the matching funds requirement for entities facing financial hardship. The Secretary may waive or reduce matching funds for entities in financial hardship when applying for a grant. Grant recipients can use funds to award subgrants to eligible local entities for grant activities. The Secretary can waive or reduce matching funds for entities in financial hardship when applying for a grant. Grant recipients can use funds to award subgrants to eligible local entities for grant activities. Subgrantees must comply with the Act's requirements. The Secretary cannot award a subgrant if the State, agency, or entity received funding for the program in the same fiscal year. $750,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2016, with additional appropriations for fiscal years 2017 through 2025. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, an "eligible local entity" includes local educational agencies, early childhood education programs, and consortia of these entities. "Full-day" refers to a day equivalent to a full school day in the state and lasting at least 5 hours. The term "full-day" refers to a day equivalent to a full school day in the state and lasting at least 5 hours. A "high-quality prekindergarten program" is supported by an eligible local entity and serves children aged 3 or 4 based on nationally recognized standards. The high-quality prekindergarten program requires children to be at least 4 years old by the eligibility determination date or have reached the legal age for State-funded prekindergarten. Teachers must meet specific qualifications, including having a bachelor's degree in early childhood education or a related field. The teacher in the early childhood education program must have a bachelor's degree, pass a State-approved assessment, engage in ongoing professional development for 2 years, and be enrolled in a State-approved educator preparation program. The teacher in the early childhood education program must have a bachelor's degree, pass a State-approved assessment, engage in ongoing professional development for 2 years, be enrolled in a State-approved educator preparation program, maintain a maximum class size of 20 children, and maintain a child to instructional staff ratio of 10 to 1. The early childhood education program maintains a maximum class size of 20 children, a child to instructional staff ratio of 10 to 1, offers a full-day program, provides developmentally appropriate learning environments, aligns with State standards, offers competitive staff salaries, conducts ongoing monitoring and evaluation, and provides comprehensive services for children. The early childhood education program offers ongoing monitoring and evaluation for continuous improvement and provides accessible comprehensive services for children, including screenings and family engagement opportunities. The early childhood education program provides comprehensive services for children, including parent conferences, support services, nutrition services, and education aligned with guidelines. The Department of Agriculture guidelines for nutrition education, programs for children with disabilities, and evidence-based physical activity programs are part of the early childhood education program. The early childhood education program includes nutrition education, programs for children with disabilities, evidence-based physical activity programs, and high-quality professional development for staff. The program provides high-quality professional development for staff, including in-class observation and evidence-based coaching. It meets education performance standards and maintains evidence-based health and safety standards. The terms "local educational agency" and "State" are defined as per the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Education.
